item.title: Nick Reiner Formally Charged With Murdering His Parents
item.description: Prosecutors said that Mr. Reiner killed his parents, Rob and Michelle Reiner, using a knife. He has not yet entered a plea.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Aude Guerrucci/Reuters
item.media:description: If convicted, Nick Reiner could be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole or the death penalty.

item.title: Why Nick Reiner Could Face the Death Penalty
item.description: The two first-degree murder counts include a special circumstance, which increases the maximum punishment if he is convicted.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
item.media:description: Nathan J. Hochman, the Los Angeles County district attorney, at a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: Rob and Nick Reiner: A Father-Son Relationship in Several Acts
item.description: Some who worked on the semi-autobiographical “Being Charlie” saw challenges play out on the set.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll

item.title: Trump Orders Blockade of Some Oil Tankers to and From Venezuela
item.description: The move is an escalation of military operations and a pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader. But its scope and economic impact are not clear.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Simon Romero, Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil tankers anchored in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Venezuela relies entirely on tankers to export its oil to world markets.

item.title: Trump Expands Travel Ban and Restrictions to 20 More Countries
item.description: People from Syria, South Sudan and those with documents issued by the Palestinian Authority are included in the latest restrictions. More than 35 countries are now under U.S. travel restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beyond the travel restrictions, the ban could have major ramifications for nationals of those countries already in the United States.

item.title: Johnson Rules Out House Vote to Extend Health Insurance Subsidies
item.description: The speaker had planned to give moderate Republicans seeking an extension of the tax credits a vote on their proposal, but said on Tuesday it was simply “not to be.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson had signaled openness to allowing debate on the proposal to extend Affordable Care Act subsidies, but ultimately rejected a bid to do so by politically vulnerable Republicans.

item.title: Trump and Top Aides Publicly Defend Susie Wiles After Explosive Interviews
item.description: President Trump praised his chief of staff as doing “a fantastic job,” and more than a dozen members of his cabinet have posted defenses of her on social media.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Susie Wiles criticized the article as a “disingenuously framed hit piece” but did not deny the authenticity of the quotes.

item.title: Suspect in Bondi Beach Killings Is Charged With Murder and Terrorism
item.description: The Australian authorities said the 24-year-old man, who had been shot by the police, woke from a coma on Tuesday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coffin of Rabbi Eli Schlanger arriving at the Chabad of Bondi for his funeral in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Grief Mixes With Anger at Funeral of Rabbi Killed in Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: The funeral for Rabbi Eli Schlanger on Wednesday was the first held for one of the 15 people killed in a mass shooting at a Jewish celebration in Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners arriving at the Chabad of Bondi on Wednesday for the funeral of Eli Schlanger, in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Australia Doubles Down on Gun Control in Wake of Bondi Beach Shooting
item.description: The country has long looked warily at the cycle of gun violence in the United States, where meaningful changes in policy have been rare.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in Sydney on Tuesday. The shooting, which left at least 15 dead and scores of others injured, has forced a hard look at gun control in Australia.

item.title: 3 Days After Deadly Brown Shooting, Killer and Motive Remain a Mystery
item.description: The authorities released more video footage in an attempt to identify a suspect, and said they had no idea why the killer attacked a study session.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin and Mitch Smith

item.title: What Would Be Lost if We Didn’t Have the HBO Comedy Special
item.description: The potential Warner Bros. Discovery sale might jeopardize a lively outlet for artier stand-up shows like those of Sarah Sherman and Adam Pally.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners Pulls Out of Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Affinity Partners, Mr. Kushner’s private equity firm, played a small financial role in Paramount’s $108 billion offer, but it had attracted political attention to the deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, founded his investment firm, Affinity Partners, shortly after the end of Mr. Trump’s first term.

item.title: Ukraine Plan Calls For Enhanced Military, With U.S. and European Backup
item.description: The latest proposal is designed to deter future Russian aggression. But Russia is not part of the talks and has shown little willingness to negotiate.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers during a live-fire training exercise at a military training ground in the Dnipro region this month.

item.title: On British Roads, Chinese Cars Are Racing Ahead
item.description: BYD, Chery and other Chinese automakers are winning over drivers in Britain, where tariffs are low and buyers are open to new brands.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Owen Richards for The New York Times

item.title: Does China Have a Robot Bubble?
item.description: The Chinese government is betting that robots will drive economic growth. But the bots can’t really do much yet.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Jade Gao/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A new Chinese humanoid robot appeared so lifelike that workers cut its leg open during a demonstration last month.

item.title: The Untold Story of How Jeffrey Epstein Got Rich
item.description: For years, rumors swirled about where his wealth came from. A Times investigation reveals the truth of how a college dropout clawed his way to the pinnacle of American finance and society.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich, Steve Eder, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein

item.title: How Jeffrey Epstein Made His Money: Six Takeaways From The Times’ Investigation
item.description: The sources of Epstein’s fortune have long been a source of speculation. Here are six takeaways from a Times investigation that found that he built it through scams, theft and lies.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, Matthew Goldstein, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and David Enrich

item.title: Norman Podhoretz, Influential Editor and Neoconservative Force, Dies at 95
item.description: A New York intellectual and onetime liberal stalwart, his Commentary magazine became his platform as his political and social view turned sharply rightward.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.media:credit: Associated Press

item.title: At Many Top Law Schools, Black Student Enrollment Continues to Drop
item.description: The New York Times examined data from 18 of the nation’s top law schools and found that first-year Black enrollment had increased at only four, including at Harvard.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Billy Hickey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard Law School in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Penguins Become Prey for the Pumas of Patagonia
item.description: In Argentina, the return of pumas brought top predators back to the landscape — much to penguins’ dismay.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: Heart Association Revives Theory That Light Drinking May Be Good for You
item.description: The American Heart Association report runs contrary to recent studies — and the group’s own guidelines — that found any amount of alcohol to be harmful.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Colin Clark for The New York Times
item.media:description: While there is no dispute that heavy drinking is harmful to health, the question before experts is whether light to moderate drinking provides more protection from cardiovascular disease than not drinking at all.

item.title: On Bali, the Holiday Vibe Masks Memories of a Massacre
item.description: Sixty years ago, half a million Indonesians were killed in anti-Communist purges. On Bali, resorts and clubs were built atop mass graves.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A graveyard on the Indonesian island of Bali where some of the victims of anti-Communist killings in the 1960s are believed to have been buried.

item.title: Chile Is Swerving to the Right — and Into the Past
item.description: Chile’s new leader wants to rewrite its past and recast its future.
item.dc:creator: Ariel Dorfman
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Eitan Abramovich/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Stephen King on Rob Reiner’s ‘Stand by Me’
item.description: In Rob’s hands, my most autobiographical novel rang true.
item.dc:creator: Stephen King
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Late Night Thanks the White House for a ‘Doozy of an Interview’
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel was grateful that Susie Wiles, the president’s “future former chief of staff,” spilled the beans on her boss in a Vanity Fair article.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Mayor Adams’s Farewell To-Do List: Praise Himself, Undermine Mamdani
item.description: Before jetting off to Mexico, Mayor Eric Adams held an unusual news conference that included a time capsule, a new theme song and a defense of his one-term tenure.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Michael Loccisano/Getty Images
item.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams is leaving for Mexico, his fourth international trip in the last three months.

item.title: In a Remote Jungle, the Gruesome Poaching of Rare Elephants
item.description: More than a dozen Bornean elephants have been killed — including five beheaded — in Malaysia in the past 18 months, the authorities say.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock, Zunaira Saieed and Sanjit Das
item.media:description: Henry Jamis, a ranger, next to the skeleton of a Bornean elephant near the Maliau Basin Conservation Area in Malaysia’s Sabah state last week.

item.title: Widow of Officer Slain in Park Ave. Attack Sues Landlord Over Security
item.description: Didarul Islam and three others were killed when a gunman came to a Midtown skyscraper. The suit says the building had few physical barriers and lax surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: The suit says the killer walked through the courtyard unimpeded and undetected, then opened fire.
